step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Market Awareness
step1_initial_points.description: The government lacks a clear understanding of the current landscape of available AI tools, solutions, and services relevant to their functions. This makes it difficult to identify suitable technologies to address their specific needs for efficiency, decision-making, and service delivery.

step1_initial_points.title: Budget Uncertainty and Cost Planning
step1_initial_points.description: Inability to forecast and allocate budget for AI initiatives without understanding the indicative costs and pricing structures of potential solutions. This uncertainty is a major obstacle to future procurement planning and investment decisions.

step1_initial_points.title: Data Security and Privacy Compliance
step1_initial_points.description: Significant concern about safeguarding sensitive government data when using AI tools. Ensuring solutions comply with strict regulations like the South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) and other cyber policies is a critical, non-negotiable requirement.

step1_initial_points.title: Integration with Existing Government Systems
step1_initial_points.description: The challenge of integrating new AI solutions, particularly those using third-party LLMs, with existing legacy government systems and platforms. They need to assess the adaptability and technical feasibility to avoid creating data silos or disrupting current operations.

step1_initial_points.title: Assessing Solution Maturity and Scalability
step1_initial_points.description: Difficulty evaluating the technical capability, reliability, and scalability of vendor AI solutions. The government needs evidence of performance in similar environments to mitigate the risk of adopting immature or unproven technology that cannot scale to meet public sector demands.

step1_initial_points.title: Need to Improve Efficiency and Service Delivery
step1_initial_points.description: Existing government processes are not as efficient as they could be, impacting service delivery, public satisfaction, and community outcomes. There is a clear mandate to explore emerging technologies like AI to boost efficiency and drive innovation.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of In-House AI Experience and Best Practices
step1_initial_points.description: The department lacks direct experience in deploying AI solutions within a government context. They need to learn from vendors' 'lessons learned' and best practices to avoid common pitfalls and accelerate their own AI adoption journey.

step1_initial_points.title: Uncertainty on How to Start (Pilots)
step1_initial_points.description: Hesitancy to commit to large-scale AI deployment without initial validation. The government is exploring pilots and collaborations as a way to trial AI solutions in real-world scenarios, allowing them to test effectiveness and de-risk wider adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Workforce Skill Gaps and Training Needs
step1_initial_points.description: The current workforce may lack the necessary skills to effectively operate new AI tools. Identifying the required training for staff is a key concern for ensuring successful adoption and maximizing the return on investment from new technology.

step1_initial_points.title: Difficulty in Strategic Procurement Planning
step1_initial_points.description: The absence of a structured 'catalogue of offerings' for AI makes project and procurement planning difficult and inconsistent. They need market information to develop coherent procurement strategies and policies to leverage AI for public benefit.

step1_initial_points.title: Unclear Internal Resource Impact
step1_initial_points.description: Uncertainty about the internal resources and infrastructure required to deploy and maintain AI solutions. This includes understanding the impact on existing IT systems, personnel, and operational workflows, which is crucial for implementation planning.

step1_initial_points.title: Need for Future-Proof Technology
step1_initial_points.description: Concern about investing in an AI solution that may quickly become obsolete. The government needs to understand vendors' plans for future enhancements and capabilities to ensure they select a tool that can evolve with their needs.

step1_initial_points.title: Validating Vendor Claims with Proof
step1_initial_points.description: Skepticism about vendor claims without concrete proof of success. The government requires demonstrations or examples of successful AI deployments in a government sector to verify technical capability, reliability, and performance.

step1_initial_points.title: Concern Over Post-Implementation Support
step1_initial_points.description: Apprehension about the level and quality of ongoing support after an AI tool is deployed. Understanding the available support arrangements is critical for ensuring long-term operational stability and addressing any issues that arise.

step2_filtered_points.title: Data Security and Privacy Compliance
step2_filtered_points.description: Significant concern about safeguarding sensitive government data when using AI tools. Ensuring solutions comply with strict regulations like the South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs) and other cyber policies is a critical, non-negotiable requirement.

step2_filtered_points.title: Budget Uncertainty and Cost Planning
step2_filtered_points.description: Inability to forecast and allocate budget for AI initiatives without understanding the indicative costs and pricing structures of potential solutions. This uncertainty is a major obstacle to future procurement planning and investment decisions.

step2_filtered_points.title: Integration with Existing Government Systems
step2_filtered_points.description: The challenge of integrating new AI solutions, particularly those using third-party LLMs, with existing legacy government systems and platforms. They need to assess the adaptability and technical feasibility to avoid creating data silos or disrupting current operations.

step2_filtered_points.title: Lack of Market Awareness
step2_filtered_points.description: The government lacks a clear understanding of the current landscape of available AI tools, solutions, and services relevant to their functions. This makes it difficult to identify suitable technologies to address their specific needs for efficiency, decision-making, and service delivery.

step2_filtered_points.title: Assessing Solution Maturity and Scalability
step2_filtered_points.description: Difficulty evaluating the technical capability, reliability, and scalability of vendor AI solutions. The government needs evidence of performance in similar environments to mitigate the risk of adopting immature or unproven technology that cannot scale to meet public sector demands.

step2_filtered_points.title: Lack of In-House AI Experience and Best Practices
step2_filtered_points.description: The department lacks direct experience in deploying AI solutions within a government context. They need to learn from vendors' 'lessons learned' and best practices to avoid common pitfalls and accelerate their own AI adoption journey.

step2_filtered_points.title: Workforce Skill Gaps and Training Needs
step2_filtered_points.description: The current workforce may lack the necessary skills to effectively operate new AI tools. Identifying the required training for staff is a key concern for ensuring successful adoption and maximizing the return on investment from new technology.

step2_filtered_points.title: Difficulty in Strategic Procurement Planning
step2_filtered_points.description: The absence of a structured 'catalogue of offerings' for AI makes project and procurement planning difficult and inconsistent. They need market information to develop coherent procurement strategies and policies to leverage AI for public benefit.

step2_filtered_points.title: Unclear Internal Resource Impact
step2_filtered_points.description: Uncertainty about the internal resources and infrastructure required to deploy and maintain AI solutions. This includes understanding the impact on existing IT systems, personnel, and operational workflows, which is crucial for implementation planning.

step3_refined_points.title: Data Security & Compliance Risk
step3_refined_points.description: Safeguarding sensitive government data and ensuring strict compliance with regulations like IPPs is a non-negotiable requirement. This represents a major risk and a critical barrier to adopting any third-party AI solution, demanding demonstrable security and data sovereignty assurances.

step3_refined_points.title: Budget Uncertainty and Cost Planning
step3_refined_points.description: The inability to forecast AI initiative costs is a major obstacle to investment and procurement. Without clear pricing structures and Total Cost of Ownership models, the government cannot allocate budget or make informed financial decisions, stalling strategic planning for AI adoption.

step3_refined_points.title: Technical Integration with Legacy Systems
step3_refined_points.description: Integrating new AI solutions with existing government systems is a significant technical challenge. The risk of creating data silos, disrupting current operations, or facing technical incompatibilities is a key barrier to adopting new tools and realizing their benefits across the enterprise.

step3_refined_points.title: Lack of Market Insight for Procurement
step3_refined_points.description: A poor understanding of the AI market landscape, solution maturity, and available offerings makes strategic procurement impossible. This gap prevents the government from identifying suitable vendors, evaluating scalability, and developing coherent policies, hindering its ability to leverage AI effectively.

step3_refined_points.title: Internal Capability & Resource Gap
step3_refined_points.description: The organization lacks the internal AI experience, skilled personnel, and understanding of resource impacts required for successful deployment. This capability gap creates uncertainty around implementation, training needs, and operational support, risking failed adoption and poor ROI.

merge_decisions.merged: Lack of Market Insight for Procurement

pain_points_final.title: Data Security & Compliance Risk
pain_points_final.description: Safeguarding sensitive government data and ensuring strict compliance with regulations like IPPs is a non-negotiable requirement. This represents a major risk and a critical barrier to adopting any third-party AI solution, demanding demonstrable security and data sovereignty assurances.

pain_points_final.title: Budget Uncertainty and Cost Planning
pain_points_final.description: The inability to forecast AI initiative costs is a major obstacle to investment and procurement. Without clear pricing structures and Total Cost of Ownership models, the government cannot allocate budget or make informed financial decisions, stalling strategic planning for AI adoption.
